Running Eclipse 3.0 M9 on Win 2K

I have created a view that allows user to dynamically change the number of 
columns in the view.  This is done by disposing and recreating the columns 
accoring to the user's setting.  The view also has a table cursor that allows 
the user to navigates the view. 

When the column setting in the view is changed, I tried to put the cursor to 
back to the correct position.  (Because the number of columns has changed, the 
data that the cursor is highlighting will move to another cell.  I want to make 
sure that the curosr is still highlighting the same data.)  

However, calling setSelection after the columns are disposed does not put the 
cursor to the correct position.  Calling tableCursor.setSelection(x, y) will 
always put the cursor at (x-1, y-1) location.

Looking at the code from M9, the table cursor has added a dispose listener.  
That dispose listener seems to be interfering with this setSelection call 
because it's running on the UI thread asynchronously. 

I will be attaching a testcase to reproduce the problem.

Created an attachment (id=11323)
Testcase

Testcase for reproducing the problem.  The table is originally created with 3
columns.  The reformat function disposes the columns and creates 4 columns for
the table.  The second call to setSelection(2, 2) does not put the cursor at
position (2, 2).  Instead, the cursor is put at (1, 1).
*** Bug 64450 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Another problem I found related to the dispose column listener.  When a debug 
session is terminated, the tab items in the Memory View is disposed. The 
dispose causes the following exception from the table cursor:

The disposal of the tab folder disposes all its children.  The children include 
the the tab items from the foloder, the tables, and the table cursor belonging 
to the tables.  

The table cursor is manually disposed before the tab folder from the Memory 
View is disposed.  However, the dispose column listener continues to handle the 
dispose event after the cursor is disposed.  The getDisplay function is called 
without checking if the cursor is disposed and results in a swt exception.
